instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2567: What is 820-2567? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
Hello all,

This board works but it has no audio, not even the chime at start up. Prohibitory sign is displayed when trying to change the audio level.
No beep sound also if no memory installed.

In system preferences > sound: there is nothing for output or input.

If I plug a audio USB adapter, it appears in the above menu, and volume control works normally.

Some measures:

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SO_AUDIO</SIGNAL>=1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP4V5_AUDIO_ANALOG</SIGNAL>=4.5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_AUDIO</SIGNAL>=5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_AUDIO</SIGNAL>=3.3V
<SIGNAL>HDA_RST_L</SIGNAL>=3.3V

but
<SIGNAL>AUD_GPIO_3</SIGNAL>=0V, so is <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_SHDN</SIGNAL>, and I understand that this is disabling all 3 amps 6610, 6620 and 6630

I was thinking about replacing <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>. Is this the good way? Other options?

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>AUD_GPIO_3</SIGNAL>=0V, so is <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_SHDN</SIGNAL>"
What do you expect there?
If 0V, means NO amp shutdown; do you want to mute it???

If no audio codec is recognized in system report, then change the codec; if has all power rails good.
Inspect for corroded traces and resistors first.

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
I don't agree. For example the datasheet of <CHIP>U6610</CHIP>, LM48556TL, says for <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_SHDN</SIGNAL> (pin SD*, number C3):
"Active Low Reset Input. Connect to VDD for normal operation. Drive SD low to disable."
So I expect 3.3V to avoid shutdown, no?
I don't find any corrosion. So, I change the CODEC, <CHIP>U6201</CHIP>?

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
I just saw that's truth.
Apple fucked off again a schematic.
Signal name should end with "_L", as active low signal.
Is only visible inside of chip marking (SD*).

I didn't even look at schematic, only thought on signal name; mea culpa.
Check <SIGNAL>HDA_RST_L</SIGNAL> first.

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
In fact it is strange, because Apple put the "_L" for <SIGNAL>HDA_RST_L</SIGNAL> (tagged RESET* inside the chip), not on <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_SHDN</SIGNAL>
Anyway, this <SIGNAL>HDA_RST_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3V. So chip is enabled, power rails ok, no corrosion: tomorrow I will try to replace my first 48 pin chip...

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
We cannot expect Apple, nor other manufacturer to simplify board repairs.
Watch Louis videos about "right to repair" hearings...

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
No luck for this one, still no sound. Either the chip was also bad, or I fucked it, or there is another issue that I don't see at all.
I also checked that there is no short on <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_SHDN</SIGNAL> on the amps, I measure 75kohm, seems ok.
So, for this one I give up :(

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
Could be MCP issue.
Try heating it, nothing to lose...

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
I heated the MCP, now I get no video and no backlight (and still no sound, even without RAM).
I checked all the rails, they are still ok
Fan spins, no red light on mouse, just the peak when starting
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>=0.99V
<SIGNAL>LVDS_IG_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL>=0V
State should be S0:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>=3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>=3.32V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>=3.32V

Probably heated too much? I put 90 seconds at 450`C, only the MCP, I protected the remaining PCB with aluminium. What would be correct time and temperature? (I know, I should have asked that before)
Any idea to get back the video? Or is it fried now?

threads.title: Board A1342 2009, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2567</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, no audio, no chime
threads.message:
MCP damaged now, I suppose.
Heat test is about 10-15s at 180-200 degrees on the die.
I do this normaly with 400 on the hotair station, at few cm away.
However, depends of the tool used.
